qas.question: Who was a threat to Shunzhi's throne?
What was Dorgon known as after death?
How old was Shunzhi at his death?

context: Although his support had been essential to Shunzhi's ascent, <a0_0>Dorgon<a0_0/> had through the years centralised so much power in his hands as to become a direct threat to the throne. So much so that upon his death he was extraordinarily bestowed the posthumous title of <a1_0>Emperor Yi<a1_0/> (Chinese: 義皇帝), the only instance in Qing history in which a Manchu "prince of the blood" (Chinese: 親王) was so honored. Two months into Shunzhi's personal rule, Dorgon was not only stripped of his titles, but his corpse was disinterred and mutilated.[b] to atone for multiple "crimes", one of which was persecuting to death Shunzhi’s agnate eldest brother, <a2_0>Hooge<a2_0/>. More importantly, Dorgon's symbolic fall from grace also signaled a political purge of his family and associates at court, thus reverting power back to the person of the emperor. After a promising start, Shunzhi's reign was cut short by his early death in <a3_0>1661<a3_0/> at the age of <a4_0>twenty-four<a4_0/> from smallpox. He was succeeded by his third son Xuanye, who reigned as the Kangxi Emperor.
